title: 110_hr415
content: Designation of Taunton River, Massachusetts. Designation of the Taunton River in Massachusetts under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, specifying different segments for scenic and recreational purposes, to be administered by the Secretary of the Interior in cooperation with the Taunton River Stewardship Council. The Taunton River in Massachusetts is designated under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, with different segments specified for scenic and recreational purposes. The 9-mile segment from Muddy Cove to the confluence with the Quequechan River is designated as a recreational river. SEC. 2. MANAGEMENT OF TAUNTON RIVER, MASSACHUSETTS. Each river segment added to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act shall be managed according to the Taunton River Stewardship Plan, dated July 2005. The plan satisfies requirements for comprehensive management under the Act. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with Massachusetts, the Taunton River Stewardship Council, and nonprofit organizations for the protection and enhancement of river segments added to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. These segments will not be administered as part of the National Park System. The zoning ordinances of certain towns and cities in Massachusetts will meet the standards of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act for land management. The zoning ordinances of towns in Massachusetts align with the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, considering each town as a village for land management purposes. The Secretary can only acquire land for river segments through donation or with the owner's consent, prohibiting condemnation. The Secretary is prohibited from acquiring land through condemnation for river segments added to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. SEC. 3. ENERGY AND CONGRESSIONAL REVIEW. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy and private industry, must submit a report to Congress detailing the energy resources available in the designated areas of the Taunton River, including specifics on energy withdrawn for development and potential for natural gas, geothermal, wind, and solar energy production. The report to Congress will detail the available wind, solar, biomass, and hydropower resources in the designated areas of the Taunton River. SEC. 4. Hunting, fishing, trapping, and recreational shooting activities in Massachusetts are not affected by this Act. Access for these activities is not limited. SEC. 5. The Act does not impact the supply of domestically-produced energy resources. Deputy Clerk: Robert F. Reeves.
